title: On the Quantitative Analysis of Craniofacial Asymmetry in 3D

author: Federico Sukno, Department of Information and Communication Technologies, Pompeu Fabra University

segmentation: Thanks very much for the introduction so.
Today I'm going to talk about facial symmetry and let me start by introducing the motivation from the application perspective.
So our interest in asymmetry is in the context of this morphology, and more specifically in the relation or the link between craniofacial dysmorphology and neuropsychiatric disorders.

The reason for this link is that during early stages of life, the face and the brain developing deep intimacy and therefore disruptions in brain development are expected to generate changes in facial geometry.
The iconic example perhaps?

Is Down syndrome where you can see clearly distinctive facial patterns in the patients affected, but specific changes in facial geometry have also been detected in another number of disorders from which I have listed a few here.

And of course, we're all a little bit asymmetric in normal context, but it is.

This has been confirmed partially in disorders such as autism, schizophrenia or fetal alcohol syndrome, but again, we find that the differences in asymmetry are very subtle, similarly to his morphology in general.
